title: The People, United, Are Not Going to Get Very Far
description: Amazon workers on Staten Island have created the company’s first union. The government needs to make it easier for others to follow.
content: Two years ago, Amazon fired Christian Smalls after he organized fellow workers at a warehouse on Staten Island to protest pandemic working conditions. On Friday, after a campaign the company bitterly opposed, the government announced that those workers had voted to unionize, and Mr. Smalls, their leader, popped open a bottle of champagne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: C.D.C. Confirms It Will Lift Public Health Order Restricting Immigration
description: The agency cited “current public health conditions and an increased availability of tools to fight Covid-19” as grounds for returning in late May to prepandemic policies for admitting migrants.
content: WASHINGTON — The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced on Friday that it would lift an emergency public health order that had restricted immigration at U.S. land borders since the beginning of the pandemic, citing “current public health conditions and an increased availability of tools to fight Covid-19.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Harry Styles Tries On Synth-Pop, and 13 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Angel Olsen, Koffee, Barrie and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Netrebko Loses Work in Russia After Seeking Distance From Putin
description: The star soprano Anna Netrebko lost work in the West over her ties to the Russian president. Now, following an about-face, she has been called a traitor at home.
content: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko, one of opera’s biggest stars, faced backlash on Friday in her home country after she tried to distance herself from President Vladimir V. Putin amid his invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanna Ingber
title: How to Make Kids Feel at Home in Both Homes After a Divorce
description: When parents go their separate ways in a divorce, children are torn between two places — both should feel like home.
content: The day my ex and I had to tell our children that we were getting divorced, we sat on the couch in the living room as they played on the rug below us. It was a pivotal moment, and our almost 5-year-old, Isaac, sensing that something big and disruptive was happening, had one very important question: What would happen to his Legos?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: Caleb Landry Jones Can Do This
description: The actor — whose latest film, the Australian drama “Nitram,” earned him a top prize at Cannes — discusses his distinctive career in challenging roles.
content: Until recent events at the Oscars, the film season’s most memorable best actor speech belonged to Caleb Landry Jones. In July, the Cannes Film Festival awarded Jones its top male thespian prize for his portrayal of a mass shooter in the Australian drama “Nitram” (now in theaters and on digital). The 32-year-old actor had been to Cannes twice before and had experienced its queasy jitters, spurred by drinking too much, sleeping too little and feeling eyeballs scan his face to gauge his importance. (“L.A., but times 50,” he said.) But this time, all eyeballs were fixed on him as he clutched the awards podium like a fainting chaise. “I think I’m going to throw up,” he sputtered. The audience tittered, uncertain if his panic was a bit. Then Jones fled the stage, leaving in his wake a few exhalations that lingered like dust clouds from a cartoon roadrunner: “I am so sorry — I cannot do this. Thank you so much.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Luke Vander Ploeg, Rachelle Bonja, Mike Benoist, Patricia Willens, Larissa Anderson, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Inside Mariupol
description: What the fight for the Ukrainian port city means for the future of the war.
content: This episode details graphic scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter, Ed Shanahan and Troy Closson
title: Boy, 12, Is Fatally Shot in a Parked Car in Brooklyn, Police Say
description: The boy was the latest child to be caught in the crossfire of a surge in shootings that has plagued New York City since the pandemic began.
content: A day after a 12-year-old boy was fatally shot in a parked car in Brooklyn, community leaders said the killing was just the latest episode to unsettle neighborhood residents who are both scared of street violence and wary of a return to aggressive police tactics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: What Will Smith and Joe Biden Have in Common
description: The slap and the slip were the same kind of gaffe.
content: President Biden’s gaffe about Vladimir Putin and Will Smith slapping Chris Rock at Sunday’s Academy Awards ceremony were demonstrations of a single phenomenon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How to Endure the Big Decline in Bonds
description: Our columnist answers questions about the troubles in the bond market, and what they mean for investors.
content: It’s been a horrible start of the year for the bond market, the worst in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Putin Knows What He’s Doing With Ukraine’s Refugees. This Is the World’s Big Test.
description: The response to Ukrainian refugees is a test of European solidarity.
content: The mass flight of refugees from Ukraine has created a humanitarian crisis that dwarfs anything Europe has seen since World War II. More than four million people have poured into neighboring countries, and as long as Russia’s savage war continues, millions more will flee. Already, the flow of refugees from Ukraine is far greater than the number from Syria, Afghanistan and Iraq who fled to Europe in 2015, upending European politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Ian Austen
title: ‘I Feel Shame’: Pope Apologizes to Indigenous People of Canada
description: Pope Francis also promised to visit Canada as part of a process of healing and reconciliation over the church’s involvement in an abusive system of residential schools.
content: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis apologized on Friday for the Roman Catholic Church’s involvement in a system of Canadian boarding schools that abused Indigenous children for 100 years, and said he would travel to Canada as part of a process of healing and reconciliation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Red Cross postpones its effort to rescue civilians from besieged Mariupol.
description: At least one group of private vehicles left the battered city, but a larger effort failed when unsafe conditions prevented a Red Cross team from reaching the city to escort an evacuation convoy.
content: A planned mass evacuation of civilians from the besieged southern city of Mariupol, facilitated by the International Committee of the Red Cross, failed on Friday, even as Ukrainian officials said that about 3,000 civilians had managed to escape the city without a Red Cross escort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed eyes a hot labor market as unemployment nears prepandemic levels.
description: Federal Reserve officials are tasked with fostering “full employment.” At least for now, some see the labor market as uncomfortably tight.
content: Federal Reserve officials are tasked with fostering “full employment,” and while it has been difficult to guess what that means as the economy recovers from huge job losses at the start of the pandemic, March hiring data seemed likely to reaffirm to policymakers that the labor market is running hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Fullerton
title: Bright Colors, Dark Subjects: Hew Locke’s Unsettling Pageant
description: In a major new commission for the Tate museum group in London, the British-Guyanese artist returns to the themes of empire and postcolonial reckoning that have fascinated him throughout his career.
content: LONDON — On a recent morning, a cavernous studio in south London was a vista of ordered chaos. Elaborate headdresses covered several tables, a jumble of cardboard cutout body parts lay heaped on a palette and boxes overflowed with leopard-print fabrics, fake fur and gaudy fake jewelry. Sewing machines whirred and hammers banged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Fires, Then Floods: Risk of Deadly Climate Combination Rises
description: A new study found that the dangerous pairing of disasters may become more common in the American West as rains trigger runaway surges of mud and debris in areas damaged by wildfire.
content: Global warming is greatly increasing the risk that extreme wildfires in the American West are followed by heavy rainfall, a new study has found, highlighting the need for better preparations for hazards, like mudslides and flash floods, that can cause devastation long after the flames from severe blazes are out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Industries hit hard by the pandemic continued their rebound.
description: Leisure and hospitality jobs are still far below their pre-Covid levels, but represent a big share of employment gains.
content: The jobs report released Friday — which showed U.S. employers added 431,000 jobs in March on a seasonally adjusted basis — received a round of applause from many economists and labor market analysts, cooling off fears of a major slowdown in growth. And it spurred hope in the service sector that good times may be back again, and stick around more sustainably.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Energy prices in Europe soar 45 percent as inflation hits another record.
description: A continued run-up in prices shows how rapidly the impact of the war in Ukraine is coursing through Europe’s economy.
content: PARIS — Soaring energy and food prices driven by Russia’s continued aggression against Ukraine pushed inflation in Europe last month to levels not seen in four decades, with prices in the 19 countries that use the euro soaring 7.5 percent, according to data released Friday by Europe’s statistics agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A. Decides Against Limiting Perchlorate in Drinking Water
description: Drinking water for as many as 16 million Americans may be contaminated with perchlorate, a chemical that can harm the development of fetuses and children.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday said it would uphold a Trump-era decision and not impose limits in drinking water of perchlorate, a contaminant that has been linked to brain damage in infants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Republicans Target Progressive Advocacy Group Amid Opposition to Jackson
description: Some Republicans have linked their criticism of President Biden’s Supreme Court nominee to the support she has received from Demand Justice, a group that wants to expand the court.
content: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of progressive activists crowded into the Hamilton music venue a few blocks from the White House on Monday night to celebrate the nomination of Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, listen to queen of funk Chaka Khan perform and hear someone, as the song goes, tell them something good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: More nations will join U.S. in releasing emergency oil reserves.
description: The International Energy Agency said member countries had agreed to a release to ease global oil markets rocked by Russia’s war in Ukraine.
content: The International Energy Agency said Friday that its 31 member nations had agreed to a new release of emergency oil reserves in what is turning into a historic, wide-reaching effort to calm global markets roiled by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: At the Fountain
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Strikes, Inflation, Now War: Uncertainty Escalates for Europe’s Travel Season
description: As pandemic restrictions lifted, the travel industry was looking forward to a strong summer season. But they may be disappointed.
content: Diego Sanz, a tour guide on Spain’s southeastern Mediterranean coast, received his first international group booking in more than a year in mid February. It was, he thought, an augury of better things to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: Using Film to Tell a Personal History of America and Race
description: With “Who We Are,” the lecturer Jeffery Robinson and the directors Emily and Sarah Kunstler follow in the tradition of documentaries that excavate our past.
content: For over a decade, Jeffery Robinson has been telling an unvarnished history of the United States in an ever-evolving lecture presentation. His talks, now presented as part of his organization, the Who We Are Project, delve into how racism against Black people was bound up with the country’s legacy since its founding. The new documentary, “Who We Are: A Chronicle of Racism in America,” captures Robinson’s eye-opening account (filmed at Town Hall in New York City) and intersperses interviews with civil rights figures and others from his travels across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: Do You Enjoy Taking Long Walks?
description: Do you see walking as an enjoyable activity, or is it just a way to get from one place to another?
content: Do you enjoy walking around your neighborhood? Have you ever discovered something interesting or surprising near where you live when walking around? During the pandemic, Mary Hosbrough and Jennifer Jacobsen-Wood tried something new: They met up daily to walk every street of their hometown, Peoria, Ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: The U.S. match schedule is set: T.B.D., then England, then Iran.
description: The Americans’ first game will come on the World Cup’s opening day, but the opponent won’t be known until June.
content: After all that waiting, the United States finally learned its World Cup schedule at the World Cup draw on Friday, and it won’t have to wait long to play once the tournament begins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: House committee opens investigation into Amazon’s labor practices.
description: A tornado that hit a delivery station in Illinois last year will be a focus of the inquiry.
content: The House Committee on Oversight and Reform has opened an investigation into Amazon’s labor practices during severe weather events, according to a letter members sent to Andy Jassy, Amazon’s chief executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Keeps Mask Mandate for Kids Under 5 as Cases Rise
description: Mayor Eric Adams made the announcement as a judge moved to strike down the requirement. Coronavirus cases are increasing again in New York, fueled by the Omicron subvariant BA.2.
content: Mayor Eric Adams announced on Friday that New York City will keep its school mask mandate in place for children under 5 in response to rising coronavirus cases in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Budi Tek, 65, Dies; His Fortune Built a Vast Trove of Asian Art
description: He was one of the world’s top collectors, and his immense Yuz Museum in Shanghai helped establish the region’s bustling art scene.
content: Budi Tek, a Chinese-Indonesian billionaire who in the 2000s emerged almost overnight as one of the world’s leading art collectors, and who later founded one of China’s largest private museums, died on March 18 in Hong Kong. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Yes, You Do Deserve a Little Treat
description: Two years into the pandemic, people are coping with big existential problems by making time for simple joys.
content: These days, whenever Jules Zucker has to run an errand, she throws a Reese’s Fast Break candy bar into her bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Verifying Images of the War in Ukraine
description: The Times’s Visual Investigations team shares the rigorous process of confirming (or disputing) the authenticity of videos about the war in Ukraine.
content: A brief, shaky video uploaded to Telegram on March 17 showed bodies on the ground in Mariupol, one of Ukraine’s largest cities, which has been battered by Russian military attacks in the continuing war. The person behind the camera shouted that it was March 13. But could the date — and the content itself — be corroborated?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M.’s and Toyota’s U.S. first-quarter sales fell sharply as a chip shortage persisted.
description: The companies struggled to produce vehicles in the first three months of the year, a sign that shortages could last longer than executives had hoped.
content: General Motors and Toyota Motor suffered significant drops in car and truck sales in the United States in the first three months of the year as the global shortage of computer chips continued to disrupt production and leave dealers with bare lots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Final Four Lore Shaped With Indelible New Orleans Moments
description: This will be the sixth Final Four held in the Superdome, and each of the previous five has provided a signature moment.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Being young, drunk or stupid is a reliable indicator of why anyone would waste a Saturday night roaming the French Quarter when the rest of the city’s musical, culinary and cultural treasures beckon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: oblivionaire
description: The teenage winner of our Invent a Word challenge suggests a noun for some leaders of the globalized economy.
content: Note: This April Fools’ Day, we’ve turned our vocabulary column over to the winner of our Invent a Word challenge, which invited students to fill a gap they saw in the English language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Bruce Arians Gave the N.F.L. a Diversity Blueprint It Shouldn’t Ignore
description: His tactical retirement plan as the Tampa Bay Buccaneers coach created an opportunity for Todd Bowles and left a pipeline of experienced Black assistant coaches and coordinators.
content: Rooney Rule? Maybe the N.F.L. should forget the Rooney Rule, which the league leans on in a halfhearted effort to increase diversity among its head coaches. What the N.F.L. needs are more leaders like Bruce Arians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: A nuclear agency is investigating reports of radiation poisoning among Russian troops at Chernobyl.
description: Russian soldiers left the decommissioned nuclear plant and a nearby city after five weeks of occupation.
content: As Russian troops pulled out of Ukraine’s shuttered Chernobyl nuclear plant five weeks after seizing it, an international nuclear watchdog agency is looking into reports that some of the soldiers are experiencing radiation poisoning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: The student loan pause is supposed to end in a month. That looks unlikely.
description: Loan servicers were told to hold off on sending bills, signaling that an extension is probably in the works.
content: On May 1, the federal government is supposed to resume collections — for the first time in more than two years — from 43 million borrowers on $1.6 trillion in federal student loan debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: Get to Know the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament
description: Every year, hundreds of crossword constructors and fans gather to compete in Stamford, Conn. This year will feature the first live Wordle competition.
content: Every year, crossword lovers and solvers come together to participate in the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Judge Tosses Out New York’s New Political Districts
description: The ruling puts the state’s June primary elections in doubt, but Democrats said they would appeal.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the latest twist in redistricting in New York. We’ll also catch up on the state budget in Albany, about to be officially late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Living With Gusto Despite a Rare, Fatal Disease, and Hunting for Answers
description: At 26, Sammy Basso is believed to be the oldest person with the disease Progeria. And now he’s researching it, hoping to find a treatment and the secrets of aging.
content: TEZZE SUL BRENTA, Italy — Like many an Italian man living at home in his mid-20s, Sammy Basso is a little embarrassed by the childhood mementos that clutter his small bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Russians Line Up Behind Putin
description: Most of the war’s opponents are leaving the country or keeping quiet.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Cuomo Sues Ethics Panel to Block It From Seizing Book Profits
description: The lawsuit is the latest example of Andrew Cuomo’s aggressive stance as he returns to public life seven months after resigning as New Yorks governor.
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo sued New York’s ethics commission on Friday, contending that its efforts to force him to turn over the proceeds of a $5.1 million book deal were a violation of his constitutional rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Yale Museum Surrenders Items as Part of Art Looting Investigation
description: The 13 artifacts, valued at more than $1 million and all from South Asia, were given to investigators who say some of them are linked to an accused antiquities smuggler.
content: Law enforcement officials have seized 13 artifacts from the Yale University Art Gallery that they say were looted. Many of those, the authorities said, are part of an ongoing investigation into Subhash Kapoor, a former Madison Avenue art dealer accused of being one of the world’s most prolific antiquities smugglers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and Matt Stevens
title: Will Smith Resigns From Academy After Slapping Chris Rock at Oscars
description: The producer of the telecast, Will Packer, said that Smith had been asked to leave after slapping Rock, and that he had urged officials not to “physically remove” the actor.
content: LOS ANGELES — Will Smith, who slapped the comedian Chris Rock at the Oscars, said Friday that he was resigning from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, saying that he had “betrayed” its trust with conduct that was “shocking, painful, and inexcusable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: Stop and Smell the Roses
description: Or take a cloud out on a walk or climb the antlers of a deer.
content: EMILE AND THE FIELDWritten by Kevin YoungIllustrated by Chioma Ebinama
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Before Love Came a Lot of Likes
description: To show interest in Jayla Moody, a fellow undergraduate at his college, Jordan Marshall liked bunch of her Instagram photos. She then did the same.
content: Jayla Moody and Jordan Marshall’s love story might have started sooner if only they had spoken during the time that both attended Mercer University in Macon, Ga., where he was the captain of the football team, and she was the 2018 Homecoming Queen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Augustin Palm
title: ‘Tokyo Vice’ Revisits a Faded Underworld
description: This cross-cultural crime thriller, which recalls a time when the yakuza ruled Tokyo’s red-light districts and back alleyways, traced a twisty path to TV.
content: TOKYO — These days there are few visible signs of the yakuza in Kabukicho, the storied entertainment and red-light district in the heart of this churning metropolis of more than 37 million people — the biggest city in the world. Aggressive laws have weakened Japan’s organized crime syndicates and chased their aging, declining memberships into the shadows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Russia’s Aggression Prompts Calls to Rethink U.S. Uranium Imports
description: The war in Ukraine has highlighted the risks of U.S. dependence on Russia for the fuel needed for nuclear energy, creating new challenges for the industry.
content: WASHINGTON — As Western leaders have raced to respond to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine with steps to reduce imports of Russian fossil fuels, U.S. lawmakers and officials are confronting a thorny dilemma over another source of energy: the Russian uranium that powers many American nuclear plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alastair Macaulay
title: Margaret M. McGowan, Who Expanded the Field of Dance History, Dies at 90
description: She took a unique interdisciplinary approach and created a new field of study by exploring the collision of politics, ballet, design and music.
content: Margaret M. McGowan, a British cultural historian who created a new international area of academic study, now known as early dance, and received national honors in both Britain and France, died on March 16 in Brighton, England. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Rogé Karma Interviews Nicholas Mulder for ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
description: A conversation with the historian.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Rogé Karma and featuring Nicholas Mulder. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The C.E.O. of a Running Company Who Can No Longer Run
description: Jim Weber, the chief executive of Brooks Running, was a devoted distance runner. Then came cancer.
content: Jim Weber, the longtime chief executive of Brooks Running, was for many years a devoted runner. The hours spent racking up the miles were more than exercise for him. They were a chance to meditate on life, to devise strategy about business, and to ruminate on the thorny problems that come with operating a company with more than $1 billion in annual sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: After the Protesters Left, an Illicit Weed Began Growing in Parliament’s Garden
description: New Zealand officials say anti-vaccination protesters seeded cannabis during a three-week occupation.
content: When anti-vaccination protesters finally cleared out of New Zealand’s Parliament grounds after a three-week occupation, they left behind a scene of destruction and disorder — the charred remains of a children’s playground, camping equipment and human waste, among other items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: The Curious Case of the Recovering Ruble
description: Why has Russia gone all out to defend its currency?
content: It has now been 37 days since Vladimir Putin’s forces reportedly thought they could capture Kyiv within 48 to 72 hours. Many news reports describe the Russian invasion as “stalled,” but as I read the detailed analyses, that isn’t quite right: Ukrainian forces are counterattacking, and in many places Russia appears to be losing ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Doctor-Approved Recipes
description: Schnitzel with grapes, pasta amatriciana and more ideas from an afternoon of playing recipe concierge.
content: One of the great joys of my job is that there are people in my life who commandeer me when I see them and tell me what they’ve made from New York Times Cooking. My favorite interactions are with my doctor, a consummate New Yorker whom I love, and who has taken care of me for many years. Yesterday, in the exam room during an appointment, she took out her phone, opened the Cooking app, and began scrolling as she gave me the rundown on recipes:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: An Olympian’s Plea Against War Resonated, but His Work Goes On
description: Vladyslav Heraskevych, a skeleton competitor from Ukraine, gathers supplies and uses the team van to deliver them to Kyiv as he waits to be called for military duty.
content: A little more than a month has passed since the end of the Beijing Olympics, but already the Games, like the ones before, have distilled into a handful of images and moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Joni Mitchell Will Make a Rare Televised Appearance at the Grammys
description: The singer-songwriter, who has spoken in public infrequently since a 2015 aneurysm, will present an award live at the ceremony Sunday night in Las Vegas.
content: When viewers tune in to the 64th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night, they will see some familiar celebrities at the microphone as presenters, including Megan Thee Stallion, Questlove, Dua Lipa, Lenny Kravitz and Jared Leto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Jurors Begin Deliberating Case of Alleged Plot to Kidnap Michigan’s Governor
description: Lawyers made closing arguments on Friday in the federal trial involving four men with militia ties who are accused of conspiring to kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer.
content: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The government’s accusations were jarring: Several men with militia ties had schemed to abduct Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan at her vacation home. The group, prosecutors and witnesses said, had held a series of “field training exercises” and discussed killing or stranding her in a boat in the middle of Lake Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Is U.S. Employment at Its Peak?
description: Despite strong job growth, all the positions lost during pandemic may not be regained.
content: This morning, the Labor Department will report how many jobs employers added to their payrolls in March. Economists expect a healthy gain. But how much longer can the labor market keep it up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Native Hawaiian Hula Teacher Among Five Women Who Will Appear on Quarters
description: Edith Kanaka‘ole, who died in 1979, will appear on the coin next year along with four other notable women.
content: George Washington will be sharing some space with a native Hawaiian hula teacher next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Refuse to cooperate with the Kremlin’s war, Zelensky tells Ukrainians and Russians.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine threatened retribution for people who collaborate with occupying forces and accused retreating Russians of planting mines and even booby-trapping corpses.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine called on ordinary people of his country and Russia alike to refuse to cooperate in Moscow’s invasion and occupation, and accused Russian forces in northern Ukraine of planting mines as they retreat, making it dangerous for people to return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Jerrod Carmichael Comes Out in a Riveting Special That’s About So Much More
description: In “Rothaniel” on HBO, the stand-up grapples with secrets that defined his upbringing, the toll silence has taken and the price he’s paying to break it.
content: In his 2014 debut special, “Love at the Store,” the stand-up comic Jerrod Carmichael offered advice to gay people about the right time to come out of the closet. “Save it until you need it,” he said, quipping: “I would come out of the closet when a friend asked me to move.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 15 Recipes for Observing Ramadan
description: As a month of fasting begins, these flavorful dishes will enliven suhoor meals and iftar celebrations.
content: With the holiest month in the Islamic calendar right around the corner, plans for suhoor and iftar meals, which bookend long days of fasting, are well underway across the globe. Below is just a sampling of recipes often found on tables across cultures and countries throughout the holiday, which begins Saturday in the United States and comes to a close with Eid al-Fitr on May 2. Some are savory, others are sweet, but all are sure to satisfy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: ‘Meatspace’? Technology Does Funny Things to Language
description: Our words reveal a lot about changes in society.
content: To celebrate April Fools’ Day I’ve tried to have some fun in this newsletter, including in the choice of reader mail and the quote of the day. Everything’s true, though — no fooling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Cannabis for Better Sex? Here’s What the Science Says.
description: The research is thin, but anecdotal experience suggests that the right dose and delivery method can make a positive difference for some people.
content: A few weeks ago, the Ask Well column highlighted treatments for low libido in women. Afterward, several readers wanted to know if cannabis could be added to the list of potential remedies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: This Man’s April Fools’ Day Prank Is a Wordle Song
description: The singer and composer Tom Rosenthal has released a song that contains only five-letter words, like the game.
content: The English singer and composer Tom Rosenthal has released an April Fools’ Day song every year since 2018, and this year’s contribution is a dreamy, Zen-like composition called “Drift Along Small World.” The song contains only five-letter words, and the lyrics float by the animated train window as Wordle entries as a passenger plays the game on his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Spike in Violence Poses Test for Israel’s Fragile Government
description: A rash of terrorist attacks has spawned criticism of the government from the left and right, and for opposite reasons. But the coalition’s diversity has constrained its options.
content: BNEI BRAK, Israel — A recent wave of terrorist attacks in Israel, the deadliest in seven years, has presented a stark challenge to Israel’s fragile coalition government, which has come under criticism from both ends of the political spectrum for policies that critics claim have compounded the risk of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: New York Mob Hit Man Escapes Custody With His Sentence Nearly Served
description: With less than a year before he would likely be released, Dominic Taddeo did not return to a halfway house in Florida earlier this week, officials said.
content: After decades in prison, and less than a year before his likely release, Dominic Taddeo apparently decided he couldn’t wait to get out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Separated but Under the Same Roof
description: Some couples who’ve ended their marriages are finding common ground right at home.
content: Kate Warren and her husband, Yanni Kotsonis, separated in early 2016. But they didn’t exactly go their separate ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: An Exuberant Take on Onions and Rice, for Passover and Beyond
description: Glistening with honey and pomegranate juice and studded with pine nuts, this baked onion and rice casserole is anything but unassuming.
content: In 2015, the Rabbinical Assembly, an international organization of Conservative Jewish rabbis, revoked the longstanding prohibition of eating kitniyot (such as legumes, beans, rice and corn) during Passover. For many Ashkenazi Jews, this meant a rabbinical green light for serving the likes of rice, lentils, chickpeas, corn, beans and spices like mustard and cardamom at the Seder table — the first significant menu change in approximately 800 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Strong Job Gains in March Keep a Flame Under the Recovery
description: The U.S. economy added 431,000 jobs and the unemployment rate fell to 3.6 percent. Wages showed sharp gains, but that has been blunted by inflation.
content: A continued torrent of consumer demand, paired with a decline in coronavirus caseloads and health restrictions, led to a burst of job creation last month, showing the staying power of the economic recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Artists and Rock Stars Mingle at the Whitney Biennial
description: The 80th edition of the museum’s survey of American art opens.
content: “It’s nice to have people back, in person, celebrating art and the next-generation artists,” said Adam Weinberg, the director of the Whitney Museum, as he welcomed more than 1,000 guests to celebrate the museum’s 80th biennial on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu, Amy Chang Chien and Paul Mozur
title: Outbreak at Shanghai Hospital Exposes Covid’s Risks to China’s Seniors
description: Coronavirus infections have spread at an elder care facility in Shanghai. Workers said deaths are increasing and resources dwindling.
content: A coronavirus outbreak is ravaging a hospital in Shanghai for older adults, underscoring the difficulties officials have had in containing infections even as the city imposed a 10-day staggered lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks are proof that it doesn’t take big bucks to scare people’s pants off with undead messiahs, unseen demons and uncanny commotions.
content: Kevin (Oghenero Gbaje) and his older sister, Brittney (DeShawn White), arrive with Brittney’s fiancé, Tony (Lenny Thomas), at their parents’ waterside cabin, only to discover that their mother, father and the neighbors have been killed. That’s when they — all three are Black — are accosted by an angry white guy (Nick Damici) with a gun.

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: How Low Will Senate Republicans Go on Ketanji Brown Jackson?
description: In seeking to discredit her, they have concocted a scary version of a Black woman  to serve up to their base.
content: When Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Supreme Court nomination reaches the Senate floor soon, every Republican who votes against her confirmation will be complicit in the abuse that the Republican members of the Judiciary Committee heaped on her.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Boy Fatally Shoots Classmate, 12, in South Carolina, Sheriff Says
description: It was not clear what led to the shooting or where the student had obtained a handgun. The two students were familiar with each other, the authorities said.
content: The authorities are investigating the fatal shooting of a 12-year-old student on Thursday by a classmate at their South Carolina middle school.

title: As Biden Pleads for More Covid Aid, States Are Awash in Federal Dollars
description: States pushed back on a plan to take back some of their stimulus money to fund President Biden’s emergency spending request. Now Congress is trying to find other ways to offset the cost.
content: FRANKFORT, Ky. — Gov. Andy Beshear has been toting oversize checks around his state in recent weeks, handing them out to city and county officials for desperately needed water improvements.

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Marching Bands
description: Brendan Emmett Quigley drums up a challenging variety puzzle.
content: MARCHING BANDS — This is always a fun puzzle to work on. The empty grid is a bit disconcerting to me — the alternating bands of gray and white have an optical-illusion effect and the lack of breaks between any of the words is intimidating. It’s hard to adjust to words running in four directions — across from right to left and up, as well as across from left to right and down. But as long as I get lucky with the across entries, or the beginnings of the bands, I find this variety grid more pleasant than frustrating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Noam Scheiber
title: Amazon Workers on Staten Island Vote to Unionize in Landmark Win for Labor
description: Despite heavy lobbying by the company, workers at the facility voted by a wide margin for a union. It was seen as a rebuke of the company’s treatment of its employees.
content: It was a union organizing campaign that few expected to have a chance. A handful of employees at Amazon’s massive warehouse on Staten Island, operating without support from national labor organizations, took on one of the most powerful companies in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: From the Start, Their Relationship Was ‘Uglies’
description: Jaclyn Tokarz met Dieter Seelig in 2015 at his bar, Plug Uglies, where she was a regular. But more than two years would pass before their romance took off.
content: When Dieter Demetrios Seelig and Jaclyn Michelle Tokarz first laid eyes on each other in 2015 at Plug Uglies, a bar he owns in Manhattan’s Gramercy Park neighborhood, both felt an immediate attraction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: U.S. Navy to Name Ship After Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
description: The ship, a replenishment oiler, is designed to carry fuel to the Navy’s operating carrier strike groups.
content: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the Supreme Court Justice who fought for women’s rights for more than a half century before her death in 2020, will have a U.S. Navy ship named after her, military officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: World Cup Draw Brings Certainty. Now Comes the Hard Part.
description: Often, draws do not mean what they seem to mean at first reading. Just ask Spain and Germany.
content: Louis van Gaal said it all with just the hint of a playful smile. The Netherlands’ draw for the World Cup was not easy, he said, with his characteristic bluntness, and nor was it lucky. It was, instead, “colorful.” That was a better word. Ecuador’s sunshine yellow, Qatar’s rich maroon, Senegal’s deep green and that blazing Dutch orange: colorful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats Worry That What Happens in Nevada Won’t Stay in Nevada
description: Democrats have long held up Nevada as a symbol of their future. But as the state’s economy struggles, it has become the epitome of the party’s midterm difficulties.
content: LAS VEGAS — Scars from the coronavirus pandemic are still visible here. Housing prices skyrocketed, with rents rising faster than almost anywhere else in the country. Roughly 10,000 casino workers remain out of work. Gas prices, now more than $5 a gallon, are higher than in every other state except California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Turner
title: How Stephen Sondheim’s Work Did (and Didn’t) Translate to the Screen
description: A new series of adaptations, documentaries and more examines the different ways the composer-lyricist left his mark on movies.
content: Stephen Sondheim, the unparalleled composer-lyricist who died in November, may have changed musical theater forever, but as a new program at the Museum of the Moving Image argues, he left his mark on film as well. Whether it’s Elaine Stritch’s screen-shattering performance of “The Ladies Who Lunch” in D.A. Pennebaker’s documentary “Original Cast Album: ‘Company’” or Madonna’s slinking around and cooing “Sooner or Later” in “Dick Tracy,” Sondheim’s work has given film audiences memorable moments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: As Gas Prices Soar, Biden’s Climate Ambitions Sputter
description: Rising costs at the pump, war in Ukraine, an emboldened fossil fuel industry and stalled legislation have imperiled President Biden’s climate agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — A year after he entered the White House with a vow that fighting global warming would be a driving priority for his administration, President Biden finds his climate agenda is mired in delay and faces legal, legislative and political headwinds that could diminish or dismantle it entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Battleground Nevada
description: The state will help determine Senate control in this year’s midterm elections.
content: Nevada, perhaps more than any other state, has showcased the potential for a more diverse America to move the country’s politics to the left. Rising numbers of Asian American and Latino residents have helped Democrats win the state in the past four presidential elections. The party also holds both of Nevada’s Senate seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miranda Green
title: U.S. Allows Hunters to Import Some Elephant Trophies From African Countries
description: After settling a lawsuit filed during the Trump administration, the Fish and Wildlife Service granted six permits to bring elephant parts into the country. It may approve more in the coming months.
content: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service informed some hunters last month that it would allow the import of six elephant trophies into the United States from Zimbabwe. The African elephant carcasses will be the first allowed into the country in five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Nathan
title: A Matzo-Based Brittle for the Modern Age
description: An adaptation of a popular chocolate matzo toffee, this recipe pairs salted peanut and caramel for a sweet-salty crunch.
content: Like so many others, I, for years, drizzled chocolate over matzo for my children at Passover, so I was no stranger to matzo treats. But somehow, I missed the creation of caramel matzo crunch, also called “matzo buttercrunch” or “matzo brittle,” its many incarnations found in cookbooks, on blogs and websites. Sometimes the provenance is recognized, but mostly not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: Russia and Ukraine Have Long Been This Filmmaker’s Subject
description: In documentaries and fictional features, including two timely new movies, Sergei Loznitsa takes a hard look at both countries, examining daily life amid war and other historic forces.
content: The scenes of German and Soviet soldiers overtaking Ukraine in Sergei Loznitsa’s “Babi Yar: Context” inevitably bring to mind the current Russian invasion of the country. For more than two decades, Loznitsa, a Ukrainian filmmaker who was raised in the Soviet Union, has chronicled the past and the present in Ukraine and Russia by revisiting historic events and depicting daily life in the grips of war and empire.
source.name: The New York Times
